description: Easy - The Licinian Laws and Reforms

questions.question: Who were the two plebeian tribunes credited with proposing comprehensive reforms?
options: Camillus and Brennus
Marcus Valerius and Appius Claudius
Titus Quinctius and Fabius Maximus
Gaius Licinius and Lucius Sextius
questions.text_reference: Section 4: The Licinian Rogations - First Proposals

questions.question: What was a 'rogatio' in Roman political terminology?
options: A temporary law that lasted only one year before expiring automatically
A veto issued by tribunes to block magistrates from taking action
A formal proposal submitted to assemblies for discussion and voting
An emergency decree issued by the dictator during military crisis
questions.text_reference: Section 4: The Licinian Rogations - First Proposals

questions.question: What was the cornerstone of the Licinian reform proposals?
options: That all citizens would have equal voting rights in all assemblies without property requirements
That at least one of the two consuls must be plebeian every year
That the Senate would be abolished and replaced with a purely plebeian assembly
That all magistrates would serve for five-year terms instead of one year
questions.text_reference: Section 4: The Licinian Rogations - Main Proposals

questions.question: In what year were the Licinian Laws finally passed and accepted by the patricians?
options: 380 BCE
370 BCE
367 BCE
360 BCE
questions.text_reference: Section 5: The Breakthrough - The Licinian Laws

questions.question: Who was the first plebeian to be elected as consul after the Licinian Laws were passed?
options: Gaius Licinius
Lucius Sextius
Camillus
Brennus
questions.text_reference: Section 5: What the Licinian Laws Established

questions.question: What did the Licinian Laws attempt to address regarding debt slavery?
options: They abolished all debt slavery immediately and freed enslaved debtors permanently
They required consuls to approve all debt slavery before it could be enforced
They established limits on creditor power and protections against arbitrary enslavement
They created a new government office specifically to manage enslaved debtors
questions.text_reference: Section 5: What the Licinian Laws Established

questions.question: How did the Licinian Laws address the issue of public land distribution?
options: Land was distributed equally to all citizens regardless of wealth or status
All public land was declared sacred and could not be given to anyone
The laws addressed land distribution, though exact terms remain unclear in sources
Public land was confiscated and redistributed only to patrician military officers
questions.text_reference: Section 5: What the Licinian Laws Established

questions.question: What did the Licinian Laws require regarding holding the same magistracy?
options: A person could hold any office repeatedly as often as they were elected
No one could hold the same magistracy twice within ten years or multiple offices simultaneously
Citizens could hold only one elected office in their entire lifetime
Magistracies could only be held by people who had served in the military for twenty years
questions.text_reference: Section 5: What the Licinian Laws Established

questions.question: The Licinian proposals included access to which emergency office previously held only by patricians?
options: The Tribune of the Plebs
The Censor
The Dictator
The Praetor
questions.text_reference: Section 4: The Licinian Rogations - Main Proposals

questions.question: How many decades did plebeians wait for the Licinian Laws to finally be passed?
options: About one decade of repeated failed proposals
About two decades of repeated blocked proposals
Over a decade or more of political deadlock and blocked reform
Over four decades of continuous negotiation and compromise
questions.text_reference: Section 4: The Licinian Rogations - First Proposals
